text: Hi, I’m Francis,
the host of this show "Cooking with Dog."
First, let’s prepare the ingredients.
Clean the kombu seaweed with a dampened towel.
The white powder contains much of the flavor
so don’t wash it off.
Wet the surface using a kitchen brush.
Next, rub the salt on both sides of the tai,
also known as sea bream.
You can also substitute your favorite type of white fish.
Coat the tai with sake.
This process will help to bring out the savory flavor
and remove the fishy odor.
Let the fish sit for 15 minutes.
Now, place the kombu seaweed onto a plate.
With a paper towel, remove the excess moisture from the tai.
And place it onto the kombu.
Add the enoki mushrooms and slice of carrot.
Then, pour the sake over the fish.
And now, bring a pot of water to a boil.
Wrap the lid with a kitchen towel
to keep the condensation from dripping.
Place the plate into the pot
and cover.
Steam the fish on high heat for about 10 minutes.
The cooking time may slightly change
depending on the size of fish so adjust it accordingly.
Be careful all of the water does not evaporate while steaming.
Now, garnish with the mitsuba parsley.
And cover again.
When the mitsuba leaves slightly soften, it is ready.
Remove the plate.
The steam is also extremely hot so be careful not to burn yourself.
The combination of the savory taste of the steamed tai and kombu,
the slight tartness and fresh aroma of the yuzu citrus
make this dish absolutely delicious.
Squeeze the yuzu juice over the tai
and add a small amount of soy sauce to taste.
Cooking fish with the bones in will add to the savory taste,
but make sure to remove them before swallowing.
You can also use fillets and still make this delicious dish.
Good luck in the kitchen!
